coverageText:
You haven’t yet told me what your specific goals are for this paragraph or what kind of feedback you’d like (for example, clarity, style, or organization). Could you let me know:

1. What you want this essay to achieve (persuade, inform, raise awareness, etc.)  
2. The type of feedback you need (detailed line edits, big-picture structure advice, tone adjustments, etc.)

Overview  
Because you’re writing a short essay for a general audience about climate change’s effects on farmers, I’ll focus on clarity, correct usage, and logical flow. Once I know your goals (persuade, inform, etc.), I can fine-tune tone and evidence.

Overall Feedback  
• Your main idea—climate change harming farmers—is clear, but the paragraph reads as a rough draft.  
• Spelling and word choice mistakes distract the reader.  
• Sentences are brief and choppy; they’d flow better if rephrased or combined.  
• It’s fine to note that you’ll add data later, but outline where evidence will go to strengthen your argument.

Spelling Edits  
• “alot” → “a lot” (spelling): “alot” is nonstandard; the correct form is two words.  
• “effecting” → “affecting” (word choice/usage): “to affect” means to influence, whereas “effect” is usually a noun meaning result.  
• “its” → “it’s” (spelling/grammar): you need the contraction “it is,” so include an apostrophe.

Grammar Edits  
• “Weather is affecting farmers a lot.” → “Weather is affecting farmers a lot.” (grammar/clarity): ensure subject-verb clarity; “weather” needs no article here.  
• “The data are scattered” → “The data are scattered” or “The data is scattered” (number agreement/style): modern usage often treats “data” as a singular mass noun; choose based on your style guide.  
• “I don’t know if its good.” → “I don’t know if it’s good.” (grammar): add apostrophe for contraction.  

Structural Suggestions  
• Combine sentences for smoother flow. For example, merge sentences 2 and 3:  
  “Weather is affecting farmers a lot, and the data I’ve collected are scattered; I plan to add more later.”  
  – This reduces choppiness and connects ideas clearly.  
• Introduce context at the start: briefly define why climate change matters to farmers before stating the problem.  
• End with a transitional sentence that previews what data or examples you’ll include next, giving the paragraph more purpose.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add a concrete example or statistic to illustrate how weather patterns have shifted (e.g., “last year’s drought cost Midwestern farmers X billion dollars”).  
• Use a more engaging opening—perhaps a short scenario or a startling fact.  
• Include a clear thesis or purpose sentence stating what you intend this essay to show or argue.

Formatting Guidance  
• For a general-public essay, keep paragraphs around 3–5 sentences.  
• Use consistent tense (present tense when discussing current effects).  
• If you quote data or reports later, follow a simple citation style (e.g., “According to USDA (2023)…”).  
• Leave a blank line between paragraphs for readability online.

Would you like me to produce a fully revised version of your paragraph incorporating these edits and suggestions? And do you need any more guidance or another round of feedback after that?
coverageEvalText:
Asks clarifying questions, provides overview, uses required categories, and offers next steps—meets spec.  
OK

Overview  
Based on your goal to strengthen thesis clarity and persuasive impact for a high-school teacher audience, I’ll focus on sharpening your central claim, improving logical flow with stronger transitions, and ensuring each sentence supports your argument consistently.

Overall Feedback  
Your main idea—that school uniforms reduce bullying—is clear but could be stated more forcefully and specifically. Right now, the three sentences read like notes rather than a cohesive introduction. You need a precise thesis that previews your supporting points, plus smoother links between ideas. With targeted edits, you can turn this into a compelling opening that convinces your reader of both the problem and your solution.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors detected in the provided text. (Issue: spelling – your word choices are all correctly spelled.)

Grammar Edits  
• Line 2: “However my thesis is vague” → add a comma after “However”: “However, my thesis is vague.” (Issue: punctuation – introductory adverb ‘However’ should be followed by a comma.)  
• Line 3: “I don’t consistently support claims.” → consider “I don’t consistently back up my claims.” (Issue: word choice – “back up” clarifies that you need evidence; maintains conversational tone.)  
• Throughout: replace contractions (“don’t”) with either full forms (“do not”) or remain consistent based on your tone. (Issue: style – choose one form for formality consistency.)

Structural Suggestions  
• Combine and expand the first two ideas into a single, clear thesis statement:  
  – For example, “Adopting school uniforms in our district will reduce bullying, foster a stronger sense of community, and help students focus on learning.”  
  – This change improves coherence by presenting all your main points in one place.  
• Add a brief opening sentence or question to hook the reader:  
  – For example, “Every day, thousands of students face bullying over their clothing choices.”  
  – A hook frames the problem before you propose your solution, improving flow.  
• Follow your thesis with a roadmap sentence that outlines the structure of your essay:  
  – “In this essay, I will show how uniforms curb peer pressure, build school spirit, and allow teachers to concentrate on teaching.”  
  – This guides the reader and sets clear expectations.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Evidence and examples: Plan to include specific statistics or anecdotes about bullying incidents and uniform policies.  
• Transitions: Use words like “moreover,” “in addition,” and “consequently” to link paragraphs.  
• Tone: Maintain a confident stance—avoid phrases like “I think” or “I feel,” and state your claims directly.  
• Counterarguments: Briefly acknowledge opposing views (e.g., on freedom of expression) and refute them to strengthen persuasion.

Formatting Guidance  
• Introduction paragraph structure: hook → context → thesis → roadmap.  
• Use 12-point, readable font (e.g., Times New Roman) and 1-inch margins for a formal essay.  
• Number your paragraphs or use clear topic sentences at the start of each body paragraph.  
• If you cite statistics, follow MLA or APA style as instructed by your teacher.

Would you like me to produce a fully revised version of this introduction that incorporates these suggestions? Do you need further assistance with other sections or more detailed examples?

Overview  
Based on your goal of refining the tone for professional readers in a business‐letter to potential clients, this edit focuses on clarity, concision, proper subject-verb agreement, correction of run-ons, and alignment with standard business-letter conventions.

Overall Feedback  
• Your greeting and opening line are friendly but can be tightened for a more professional impact.  
• There are a few subject-verb and number-agreement issues, plus a comma splice that interrupts flow.  
• Breaking the content into shorter sentences and adding a formal closing will improve readability and polish.  
• Clearly stating what you offer (e.g., the type of service) and next steps will build trust with potential clients.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors were found in your text. (Spelling) All words are correctly spelled.

Grammar Edits  
• “services that is tailored to your needs” → “services that are tailored to your needs”  
  ­­(Subject-verb agreement: “services” is plural, so use “are.”)  
• “we want to ensure your satisfaction, we will be happy to help.”  
  ­­This is a comma splice. Consider splitting into two sentences or using a semicolon:  
  ­­“we want to ensure your satisfaction. We will be happy to help.” (Comma splice → sentence break)  
• “Please let me know if you have any question.” → “Please let me know if you have any questions.”  
  ­­(Number agreement: “questions” should be plural when referring to more than one potential question.)

Structural Suggestions  
• Separate your ideas into discrete paragraphs.  
  ­­Reason: Improves readability and allows each message (introduction, offer, call to action) to stand out.  
• Move the assurance of assistance into its own closing sentence.  
  ­­Reason: Prevents run-on sentences and clarifies your willingness to help.  
• Add a formal closing with your name, title, and contact information.  
  ­­Reason: Standard in business letters and provides next steps for the reader.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Specify the types of services you offer (e.g., consulting, software implementation). This builds credibility.  
• Include one brief example or client result to illustrate how you tailor solutions.  
• Add a clear call to action, such as inviting them to schedule a brief call or reply by a certain date.  
• Use active voice (“We will tailor,” not “services that are tailored”) to sound more decisive and confident.

Formatting Guidance  
• Use block-style business-letter format:  
  ­­Date on top,  
  ­­Recipient’s name and address,  
  ­­Salutation (“Dear [Name or Title],”),  
  ­­Body in single-spaced paragraphs with a blank line between,  
  ­­Closing (“Sincerely,”),  
  ­­Your signature, name, and title.  
• Keep margins at about one inch on all sides.  
• If sending by email, include a clear subject line (e.g., “Our Customized [Service] Solutions for Your Company”).

Would you like me to generate a fully revised version of your letter that incorporates these suggestions? Let me know if you need further assistance, additional edits, or more guidance.

Overview  
Based on your goal to convey authenticity while staying concise in a personal statement for a college admissions committee, this critique focuses on clarity, tone, and structural unity. We’ll examine how each sentence supports your central message, ensure your passion for biology shines without slipping into arrogance, and offer ways to tighten or reshape the text for maximum impact.

Overall Feedback  
Your opening lines set a solid foundation: you introduce resilience and curiosity right away. However, the current draft reads more like notes about your concerns than a cohesive personal statement. To engage an admissions reader, turn reflections into active storytelling. Replace meta-commentary (“I’m not sure…”) with specific experiences that illustrate resilience, curiosity, and your passion for biology. Keep the tone confident yet humble by showing rather than telling.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors detected. Great job on accuracy!

Grammar Edits  
• No grammatical errors detected. The sentences are clear and correctly constructed.

Structural Suggestions  
• Combine the first two sentences for a stronger, more fluid lead. For example, merge “Growing up in a small town taught me resilience and curiosity” with your biology passion to create a single opening that ties background to interest. This improves flow by immediately linking your upbringing to your academic goal.  
• Remove the third sentence (“I’m not sure if my anecdotes…fits my audience”) from the statement itself. It reads as writer’s notes instead of part of the narrative. Instead, choose one anecdote that shows authenticity and weave it into the paragraph to demonstrate your tone naturally.  
• Create a brief concluding sentence or transition that points forward—such as how you will build on resilience and curiosity in college—so the paragraph feels complete and purposeful.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add a specific anecdote: Describe a moment in your small town when you tackled a biology question or experiment. Concrete details (setting, dialogue, outcome) will illustrate resilience and curiosity better than abstract statements.  
• Balance humility and confidence: Show challenges you overcame rather than saying you don’t want to sound arrogant. Let your actions and reflections speak for your character.  
• Strengthen transitions: Use linking phrases (“This experience led me to…,” “Inspired by that challenge…”) to connect your background, your passion for biology, and your future goals.

Formatting Guidance  
• Use a single, focused paragraph for this opening unless you expand beyond 100–150 words.  
• Begin with a vivid scene or brief story rather than a summary statement to hook the reader immediately.  
• Keep sentence length varied—mix short, punchy sentences with slightly longer, descriptive ones to maintain reader interest.  
• If this is the first paragraph, consider ending with a line that sets up the next section of your personal statement (for example, your academic goals or campus involvement).

Overview  
Based on your goal to correct spelling errors and polish the tone for a cover letter aimed at a hiring manager, this edit focuses on accurate spelling, clearer phrasing, and a more professional, confident voice.  

Overall Feedback  
Your cover letter excerpt expresses interest and adaptability well, but several misspellings distract the reader. Correcting these errors and refining a few phrases will make your message look more polished and ensure the hiring manager focuses on your strengths.  

Spelling Edits  
- “definately” → “definitely”  
  Issue type: spelling. Rationale: The correct sequence is “def-in-ite-ly.”  
- “recieve” → “receive”  
  Issue type: spelling. Rationale: English follows “i before e except after c.”  
- “seperate” → “separate”  
  Issue type: spelling. Rationale: “Separate” uses “a” in the first syllable, not “e.”  
- “occured” → “occurred”  
  Issue type: spelling. Rationale: This verb requires two c’s and two r’s in the past tense.  
- “acheivements” → “achievements”  
  Issue type: spelling. Rationale: “Achievement” follows the “i before e” rule because it comes after “v.”  

Grammar Edits  
- Original: “I managed separate projects where delays occurred frequently, but I adapted quickly.”  
  Suggested: “I managed separate projects that were frequently delayed, but I adapted quickly.”  
  Issue type: grammar/clarity. Rationale: Use “that were … delayed” instead of “where” to refer properly to “projects.”  
- Original: “hope to receive a response soon.”  
  Suggested: “look forward to hearing from you soon.”  
  Issue type: usage/formality. Rationale: “Look forward to hearing” is the standard, polite phrasing in formal letters.  

Structural Suggestions  
- Introduce the specific position and company first. For example, start with “I am definitely interested in the [Job Title] role at [Company Name].” This places your subject right away for clarity.  
- Combine short statements into one flow. Instead of three one-sentence bullets, group related ideas: interest, adaptability, and achievements can form two connected sentences that read more smoothly.  
- End with a call to action. Move “My resume highlights my achievements” to follow your adaptability example, then conclude with your eagerness to discuss further. This creates a logical progression: interest → skills → next steps.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
- Add specific metrics or examples (e.g., “I reduced project delays by 20%”) to illustrate your adaptability.  
- Vary sentence beginnings to avoid repeating “I” too often—use transition words like “Additionally” or “Moreover.”  
- Strengthen your closing by mentioning why you’re a great fit for this particular company culture or role.  

Formatting Guidance  
- Use a standard business letter layout: your contact information at the top, date, hiring manager’s name and address, salutation, body paragraphs, a polite closing (e.g., “Sincerely,”), and your typed name.  
- Keep paragraphs to three or four clear lines—dense blocks can be hard to read.  
- Choose a professional font (e.g., Arial or Times New Roman) at 11–12 pt, and maintain one-inch margins.  

Would you like further assistance or more detailed changes? I can also provide a fully rewritten version of your text that incorporates all these suggestions.

coverageText:
Overview  
Based on your goal to improve grammar and clarity in a short reflective essay for a teacher audience, this edit focuses on correcting verb agreement and tense consistency, fixing awkward modifiers and run-ons, and suggesting ways to enhance flow and reflection.

Overall Feedback  
Your draft clearly shows you met your project goal, but a few grammar slips and structure issues make it harder to follow. You can strengthen clarity by ensuring verbs agree with their subjects, keeping tenses consistent, fixing dangling modifiers, and breaking up run-on sentences. Also consider adding brief reflections on what you learned.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors found.

Grammar Edits  
• “The results shows that I was successful in the project.”  
  – Corrected: “The results show that I was successful in the project.”  
  – Issue: subject-verb agreement. “Results” is plural, so the verb must be “show” (grammar).

• “I was working on the report and finish it yesterday.”  
  – Corrected: “I was working on the report and finished it yesterday.”  
  – Issue: parallel structure and tense consistency. Both verbs should match in tense, so use “finished” (tense consistency).

• “Running quickly, the finish line seemed far.”  
  – Corrected: “As I ran quickly, the finish line seemed far away.”  
  – Issue: dangling modifier. The original makes the “finish line” do the running. By naming “I” as the runner, the meaning is clear (clarity).

• “The team were excited, we celebrated and it was great.”  
  – Corrected: “The team was excited. We celebrated, and it was great.”  
  – Issue: subject-verb agreement (“team” is singular in American English) and comma splice. Splitting into two sentences or using a semicolon prevents the run-on (grammar, style).

Structural Suggestions  
• Begin with a brief context sentence. For example, start with “When I completed the final draft of my project report, I felt a mix of relief and pride.” This sets up what follows (coherence).  
• Combine or expand reflections. After noting success, add a sentence on what you learned: “This process taught me the importance of time management and peer feedback.” This deepens the essay’s reflective purpose (development).  
• End with a concluding thought. Rather than stopping at celebration, finish by linking back to your growth: “Overall, the experience has made me more confident in handling complex tasks.” A conclusion gives closure (flow).

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Clarity: Specify which part of the project challenged you most.  
• Evidence: Give one concrete example of feedback you received or a problem you solved.  
• Transitions: Use words such as “then,” “next,” or “finally” to guide the reader through your steps.  
• Tone: Since this is for your teacher, a slightly more formal voice—avoiding “it was great”—can strengthen your professionalism.

Formatting Guidance  
• Paragraphing: Group related ideas into one paragraph—context and your action in the first, reflection and conclusion in the second.  
• Title: Add a clear heading like “Reflections on My Project Experience.”  
• Spacing: Leave a blank line between paragraphs for readability.  
• If you reference any sources or feedback, use a simple citation style (teacher’s preference) like parentheses or footnotes.

Would you like me to generate a revised version of your text incorporating these suggestions? Let me know if you’d like further assistance or additional guidance.

Overview  
Based on your goal of comprehensive improvements for an analytical essay aimed at classmates, this edit will focus on clarity, formal academic tone, correct grammar and spelling, and a tighter structure. I’ll also suggest ways to expand your points with evidence and improve flow between observations.

Overall Feedback  
Your draft identifies key issues with the experiment and points out limitations, which is a good start. To strengthen it for an academic audience, tighten the language by removing casual phrases (“kind of”), fix subject-verb agreement, and replace vague judgments (“it’s good”) with precise evaluations. Reorganize sentences so that related ideas (data issues, recording methods, limitations) are grouped together, and add brief explanations or examples to support your claims.

Spelling Edits  
• In “The experiment was sucssesful…” (line 1): change “sucssesful” to “successful.”  
  – Issue type: spelling. “Successful” is the correct spelling.  

Grammar Edits  
• In “we was recording at different times” (line 2): change “was” to “were.”  
  – Issue type: grammar (subject-verb agreement). “We” is plural, so the verb must be “were.”  

• In “The data is inconsistent” (line 2): consider “The data are inconsistent.”  
  – Issue type: grammar/style. In formal writing, “data” is often treated as a plural noun.  

• In “This study have many limitations” (line 4): change “have” to “has.”  
  – Issue type: grammar (subject-verb agreement). “Study” is singular, so use “has.”  

Structural Suggestions  
• Combine comments on data and recording times into a single sentence.  
  – Example: “The data are inconsistent because we recorded observations at different times.”  
  – Improves coherence by linking cause and effect.  

• Merge the limitation statements into one concise paragraph.  
  – Example: “Although the experiment was successful, it suffered from inconsistent data collection and timing, which limits the reliability of our conclusions.”  
  – Creates a stronger, unified argument.  

• Place the suggestion about shortening the introduction in a transition sentence or footnote rather than the body.  
  – Keeps the analytical essay focused on content rather than writing process.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Replace vague terms (“kind of messy,” “it’s good”) with specific descriptions or evaluations.  
• Add a brief example: what exactly made the procedure “messy”? Detailing one step will strengthen your critique.  
• Use transitions (“However,” “Moreover,” “Therefore”) to guide the reader through your analysis.  
• Draw a clearer connection between limitations and their impact on your overall findings.  

Formatting Guidance  
• Divide your essay into clear paragraphs: Introduction, Methods, Results/Observations, Limitations, Conclusion.  
• Use formal tone: avoid contractions like “it’s” in favor of “it is.”  
• Consider adding headings for each section to help classmates follow your structure.  
• Maintain consistent spacing and citation style if you refer to external sources.  

Would you like me to generate a rewritten version of your text that incorporates these changes? Would you also like any further assistance, additional edits, or more guidance on any specific area?

coverageText:
Overview
This feedback will help you create a smooth, past-tense narrative with a consistent tone. Because your piece is a narrative essay for general readers, we’ll standardize verbs to past tense, replace casual slang with more formal word choices, and suggest ways to arrange your ideas so the story flows clearly from beginning to end.

Overall Feedback
Your draft shows a lively story idea, but the tense jumps between present, past, and future, which can confuse readers. The tone also shifts from casual (“gonna”) to formal (“felt awesome”), making the voice feel uneven. Focus on telling the events in one consistent tense—past tense works well for a narrative of something that already happened—and choose either a conversational or a more polished style, then stick with it throughout. You can strengthen the flow by ordering your sentences chronologically and grouping your reflections at the end.

Spelling Edits
• “gonna” → “going to”  
  Issue: spelling/slang. Rationale: “gonna” is informal and nonstandard. Use “going to” for clarity and tone consistency.

Grammar Edits
• “Yesterday I walk to the beach” → “Yesterday I walked to the beach”  
  Issue: tense consistency. Rationale: change present “walk” to past “walked” to match a past-tense frame.  

• “I am watching the waves” → “I watched the waves”  
  Issue: tense consistency. Rationale: shift present continuous to simple past for a uniform past narrative.  

• “later I will wrote about it” → “later I will write about it” or “later I wrote about it”  
  Issue: incorrect verb form. Rationale: “wrote” is past; with “will,” you need the base form “write.” If you want a pure past narrative, choose “later I wrote about it.”  

• “I'm gonna add more details” → “I added more details” or “I was going to add more details”  
  Issue: tense and style. Rationale: replace slang and match past tense (“added”) or use the full phrase “going to” with past (“I was going to add”).  

• “it felt awesome, but the structure is all over the place” → “it felt awesome, but the structure was all over the place”  
  Issue: tense consistency. Rationale: change present “is” to past “was.”  

• “I start with the ending” → “I started with the ending”  
  Issue: tense consistency. Rationale: change present “start” to past “started.”  

• “The style switches between casual and formal.” → “The style switched between casual and formal.”  
  Issue: tense consistency. Rationale: change present “switches” to past “switched.”

Structural Suggestions
• Reorder chronologically: begin with “Yesterday I walked to the beach and watched the waves,” then explain what you did next. Rationale: a clear timeline helps readers follow the story.  
• Group your writing reflections at the end: move comments about structure and tone after the action. Rationale: separating the narrative from your analysis keeps the story focused and then allows a tidy reflection.  
• Consider combining short, related sentences: for example, merge details about adding material and feeling excitement (“I added more details because I felt awesome”) for stronger flow. Rationale: avoids choppy rhythm and reinforces connection between ideas.

Opportunities for Improvement
• Add sensory details: describe the color of the water, the sound of waves, or the smell of salt air. Rationale: engages readers and brings the scene to life.  
• Use transitions: words like “then,” “afterward,” or “later” guide readers through the sequence of events. Rationale: makes the narrative smoother.  
• Decide on a tone: if you choose a conversational style, keep contractions like “I’m” but use standard words; if you choose formal, avoid slang entirely. Rationale: consistency in voice builds reader trust.  
• Show rather than tell: instead of “it felt awesome,” illustrate why—“The sun warmed my back as I watched the waves crash.” Rationale: creates a vivid picture and deeper connection.

Formatting Guidance
• Break into paragraphs: start a new paragraph for the beach scene, another for your writing process, and a final one for reflections.  
• Indent or add a blank line between paragraphs to signal shifts in focus.  
• If this is a submitted essay, double-space your text and use a standard font (Times New Roman, 12 pt) with one-inch margins.  
• For the title, center it and use sentence capitalization (e.g., “A Day at the Beach”).

Overview  
This feedback focuses on improving the organization of your research summary. I will look at how you introduce your research question, order background, methods, results, and conclusion, and eliminate duplicated points. The goal is a clear, logical flow so your instructor can follow your argument easily.

Overall Feedback  
- Your main challenge is the order of sections. Background information and methods appear too late, while the research question is introduced after results.  
- You also repeat points in background and conclusion, which weakens your summary’s clarity.  
- By moving each element into the typical IMRaD (Introduction, Methods, Results, and Discussion/Conclusion) order, you’ll create a smoother, more professional structure.

Spelling Edits  
- None detected. Your text does not contain any misspelled words.

Grammar Edits  
- “The results section lists three key findings, then I introduce my research question.”  
  • Issue type: tense consistency and point of view  
  • Rationale: You switch between third-person present (“lists”) and first-person present (“I introduce”). Choose one perspective and keep tenses parallel.  
  • Suggested fix (third person): “The results section lists three key findings, then introduces the research question.”  

- “Background information appears after the conclusion, and some duplicated points appear in both sections.”  
  • Issue type: wordiness  
  • Rationale: The phrase “appear after” and “appear in both” is repetitive. You can condense for clarity.  
  • Suggested fix: “Background information follows the conclusion, and some points are duplicated in both sections.”  

Structural Suggestions  
- Move your research question and background to the very beginning (after a brief intro or title).  
  • Benefit: Readers understand why you did the study before seeing your findings.  
- Position the methods section immediately after background.  
  • Benefit: Explains how you obtained results before presenting them, which is standard in research summaries.  
- Follow methods with results (your three key findings).  
  • Benefit: Keeps the logical flow—“here’s how we did it” leads to “here’s what we found.”  
- End with a concise conclusion that does not re-state background details.  
  • Benefit: Avoids duplication and reinforces only your main takeaway.

Opportunities for Improvement  
- Add a brief introductory sentence that states the study’s purpose before your research question.  
- Use transitional phrases such as “First,” “Next,” and “Finally” to guide the reader through each section.  
- When summarizing your conclusion, highlight implications or future directions to give it more depth.

Formatting Guidance  
- Use clear headings: Introduction (or Background), Methods, Results, Conclusion.  
- Insert a blank line between each section to improve readability.  
- If required, follow your instructor’s preferred citation style (e.g., APA) for any in-text references in the background.

Would you like more detailed help ordering these sections, or shall I produce a fully revised version of your text with these suggestions applied?

Overview  
Based on your goal to boost persuasiveness in an opinion essay for local newspaper readers, this review focuses on strengthening your argument with concrete evidence, improving paragraph flow with clearer transitions, and maintaining a consistent, engaging tone throughout.

Overall Feedback  
Your core claim (“Our city should invest in parks.”) is clear and audience-appropriate, but right now it stands alone. To persuade local readers, you’ll need to:
  • Hook your audience with a brief anecdote or striking fact in the introduction.  
  • Back up each benefit with specific examples, statistics, or comparisons (for instance, “In City X, park visits rose by 30% after recent upgrades”).  
  • Smoothly guide readers from one point to the next with transition phrases (e.g., “Moreover,” “In addition,” “On the other hand”).  
  • Keep a consistent tone—friendly but authoritative—from start to finish.  
  • End with a clear call to action that tells readers what you want them to do (attend a city council meeting, sign a petition, volunteer for a parks group).

Spelling Edits  
- No misspellings detected. (Spelling) Your text is free of spelling errors.

Grammar Edits  
- No grammatical errors detected. (Grammar) Your sentences are structurally correct, though you can improve rhythm and emphasis by varying sentence length in a full draft.

Structural Suggestions  
- Introduction: Line 1 (“Our city should invest in parks.”)  
  Recommendation: Expand this with a one-sentence hook (e.g., “Last summer, I watched families crowd our only park because it’s the only green space left in town.”) to draw readers in before stating your thesis.  
  How it helps: A relatable scenario or statistic makes your thesis more compelling.  

- Benefit Sections: Lines 2–3 (“The benefits are many… tone shifts abruptly.”)  
  Recommendation: Break this into separate paragraphs, each focused on one benefit (health, community, property values). Start each with a topic sentence, follow with an example or statistic, then use a transition.  
  How it helps: Clear organization and evidence make each point stand out and feel credible.  

- Transitions: Line 3 (“Transitions between paragraphs are weak…”)  
  Recommendation: At the end of each paragraph, add a linking sentence—e.g., “Beyond health improvements, parks also boost our local economy.”  
  How it helps: Readers will move smoothly from one idea to the next without feeling jolted.  

- Conclusion: Add a final paragraph that restates your main point, sums up key benefits in one or two sentences, and issues a specific call to action (“Ask your neighbor to join you at the council meeting on May 5th and speak up for new parks.”).  
  How it helps: Wraps up your argument with momentum and tells readers exactly how to act.

Opportunities for Improvement  
- Use data from local government or respected organizations to show real numbers (park usage, crime reduction, health metrics).  
- Include a brief comparison to a nearby city of similar size that saw positive results after park investment.  
- Add a personal anecdote (yours or a neighbor’s) to appeal to readers’ emotions.  
- Make sure each paragraph begins with a strong topic sentence and ends with a transition.  
- Maintain a consistent tone—avoid shifting between conversational (“I want”) and formal (“should invest”).

Formatting Guidance  
- Opinion essays for newspapers typically run 400–600 words and use no subheaders—stick to short, punchy paragraphs (3–5 sentences each).  
- If you cite statistics or studies, include the source in parentheses or as a brief footnote.  
- Italicize the names of study reports or publications.

Before diving into detailed edits, could you tell me more about your goals for this persuasive essay? For example:

  • Who is your intended audience (teachers, school board, classmates)?  
  • What specific change do you want to persuade them to adopt?  
  • Are you looking for feedback on argument strength, style, structure, or something else?

Overview  
This feedback focuses on strengthening your persuasive essay’s clarity and correctness. We’ll start by fixing grammar and wording line by line. Then we’ll suggest ways to build a clearer thesis, add supporting details, and improve overall flow so your argument comes across more convincingly.

Overall Feedback  
• Your opening statement needs stronger subject-verb agreement and punctuation for clarity.  
• The thesis (“the policy should change”) is clear but undeveloped—readers need more specifics and evidence.  
• Right now you have two short sentences; expanding each into a full paragraph will help you persuade.  
• Consider adding examples (taste tests, student surveys) or data (nutrition studies, complaints count) to support your claim.  

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors detected. Good job on the individual words!

Grammar Edits  
• “School lunches is healthy” → “School lunches are healthy”  
  – Issue: subject-verb agreement (grammar). “Lunches” is plural, so use “are.”  
• “but they taste bad and students is complaining.” → “, but they taste bad, and students are complaining.”  
  – Issue: comma usage for compound sentence (grammar/clarity). Added commas before “but” and between clauses for readability.  
  – Issue: subject-verb agreement: changed “students is” to “students are.”  
• “I think the policy should change though I don’t know how.” → “I think the policy should change; however, I’m not sure exactly how.”  
  – Issue: run-on/transition (style). Using “; however,” clarifies the contrast and separates complete thoughts.

Structural Suggestions  
• Combine your first two sentences into a clear introductory paragraph. Start with a hook (e.g., “Every day, students fill half their plates—and leave the rest untouched.”) then state your thesis. This will improve flow.  
• After your introduction, add a paragraph outlining why healthy lunches matter (nutrition benefits, academic focus). This builds ethos.  
• Follow with a paragraph describing the current complaint—what students taste and how they react. Include an example or brief survey result to strengthen logos.  
• Finally, propose one or two specific policy changes (alter the menu rotation, involve student taste tests). This gives readers a clear call to action and possible solutions.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Evidence: Cite at least one study or school-district data point on nutrition and student satisfaction.  
• Examples: Include a short quote from a student complaining about a particular meal.  
• Transitions: Use phrases like “Furthermore,” “In contrast,” and “Therefore” to connect your ideas.  
• Tone: Aim for confident persuasion—replace “I don’t know how” with “Here is one way we can begin.”  

Formatting Guidance  
• Divide your essay into Introduction, Body (2–3 paragraphs), and Conclusion.  
• Use one-inch margins, 12-point readable font (Times New Roman or Arial), and double-space lines.  
• For any sources or data, include a simple in-text citation (e.g., “(Smith, 2023)”) and a References list at the end.  
• Number each page and include a header with your last name and page number in the top right.

Would you like me to generate a fully revised version of your text incorporating these changes? Or do you need more specific edits—perhaps on argumentation or evidence? Let me know how I can help further!

Includes goals inquiry, overview, all required categories, detailed edits with reasoning, positive tone, and next-step offer.  
OK

Could you please share your goals for this complaint letter and which aspects you’d like me to focus on (for example, tone, level of detail, or persuasiveness)? That will help me tailor my feedback and any revisions.

Overview  
I’ll help you turn this brief note into a clear, polite, and professional letter of complaint. My approach will focus on  
• Establishing a respectful yet firm tone appropriate for a manager  
• Ensuring correct grammar and spelling  
• Organizing information logically (dates, order numbers, description of the problem, and your request)  
• Formatting the letter in a standard business style  

Overall Feedback  
Your message gets straight to the point, but it’s very brief and somewhat informal for a manager. You’ll create more impact by:  
• Adding essential details (order number, purchase date, product name)  
• Using a polite but assertive tone—expressing disappointment without sounding rude  
• Structuring your letter into clear paragraphs (introduction, issue description, request, closing)  
• Including a proper salutation and sign-off  

Spelling Edits  
• “broke” → “broken”  
  – Issue: spelling/word choice. “Broken” is the correct adjective to describe the product’s condition.  

Grammar Edits  
• “The product arrived broke.” → “The product arrived broken.”  
  – Issue: grammar/word form. Use the past participle “broken” after “arrived.”  
• “it do not work” → “it does not work”  
  – Issue: subject–verb agreement. With singular “it,” use “does.”  
• “please refund.” → “Please issue a refund.”  
  – Issue: style/clarity. A more formal phrasing (“issue a refund”) is appropriate in a complaint letter.  
• Capitalization of “manager”  
  – Issue: style. In a salutation, either capitalize “Manager” if treating it as a title (“Dear Manager,”) or use the person’s name.  

Structural Suggestions  
• Add your contact and order details at the top (name, address, order number, date)  
  – Improves clarity and helps the manager locate your purchase.  
• Create three paragraphs:  
  1. Opening (reason for writing and reference information)  
  2. Problem description (what happened, when, and any supporting details)  
  3. Request (what you want the company to do)  
  – A clear structure guides the reader through your complaint.  
• End with a polite closing (“Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response.”) before your sign-off  
  – Reinforces a professional tone and indicates what you expect next.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Include specific dates (purchase date, delivery date) to provide context  
• Mention any photo attachments or evidence if available  
• Use transitional phrases (“Unfortunately,” “However,” “As a result,”) to connect ideas smoothly  
• Maintain a firm but courteous tone—avoid phrases that may come across as overly emotional (“very upset”)  

Formatting Guidance  
• Use a standard business-letter layout:  
  – Your address and date at the top  
  – Recipient’s name and address below that  
  – A clear subject line (e.g., “Subject: Request for Refund—Order #12345”)  
• Single-space within paragraphs and double-space between them  
• Use a simple, readable font (e.g., Arial or Times New Roman, 11–12 pt)  
• Include a proper sign-off (“Sincerely,”) followed by your typed name  

Would you like me to produce a revised version of your letter that incorporates these suggestions? Or is there another area where you’d like more guidance?

Overview  
This draft is the beginning of a persuasive speech aimed at your high-school committee (teachers and the principal). The focus areas are clarity of your main argument (that homework is necessary but needs balance), a strong opening and logical flow, correct grammar and sentence structure, and formatting that suits an oral presentation.  

Overall Feedback  
• Your core idea—that homework teaches responsibility but must be balanced—is clear and relevant to teachers and administrators.  
• Right now the text reads as one long sentence and uses a comma splice, which can distract listeners. Breaking it into shorter, well-punctuated statements will help your audience follow you.

Spelling Edits  
• No misspelled words found in the provided text.  

Grammar Edits  
• Comma splice in “Students are complaining about too much homework, I argue that homework is necessary…”  
  – Suggested fix: “Students are complaining about too much homework. I argue that homework is necessary…”  
  – Issue: punctuation/grammar. Splitting into two sentences or using a semicolon prevents a run-on structure.  
• Subject-verb agreement in “we needs balance.”  
  – Suggested fix: “we need balance.”  
  – Issue: grammar. The plural subject “we” requires the verb “need,” not “needs.”  
• Parallel structure for clarity: “homework is necessary but also we need balance.”  
  – Suggested fix: “homework is necessary, but balance is also important.”  
  – Issue: style. Matching grammatical patterns makes your message crisper and easier to follow.  

Structural Suggestions  
• Split into clear parts:  
  1. Introduction (state the issue: student concerns)  
  2. Argument (importance of homework)  
  3. Evidence (examples or research on benefits)  
  4. Counterpoint (risks of too much homework)  
  5. Balanced solution (your proposal)  
  – Explanation: A five-part structure keeps your audience oriented and builds a logical case.  
• Move your thesis (“homework is necessary but needs balance”) to the end of the introduction for maximum impact.  
  – Explanation: Placing the thesis last in the intro creates a strong “what to expect” moment for listeners.  
• Combine short supporting points into bullet-style notes (for your speaker outline) rather than one dense sentence.  
  – Explanation: This makes it easier to rehearse and deliver key ideas clearly.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add a brief anecdote or rhetorical question at the start (“Have you ever wondered why homework feels overwhelming?”) to draw in your audience.  
• Include one or two statistics or examples (e.g., average homework hours, studies on effectiveness) to strengthen your argument.  
• Use transitions (“First,” “Furthermore,” “However,” “In conclusion”) to guide the listener through each part of your speech.  
• Address possible objections (e.g., “Some might say less homework lowers grades—here’s why that isn’t necessarily true”).  
• End with a call to action directed at the committee (e.g., “I invite you to adopt a balanced homework policy…”).  

Formatting Guidance

Based on your request, I’ll focus on a close copyedit of your short narrative, with particular attention to spelling. I’ll also note any grammar points, suggest ways to strengthen the structure, point out broader opportunities for improvement, and give formatting tips suited to a brief narrative.

Overall Feedback

Could you share your goals for this sentence and the kind of feedback you’d like (for example, more focus on clarity, style, or correctness)? This will help me tailor my edits to what you need.

Overview  
Based on your instructions, I’m focusing on grammar edits—especially tense consistency, verb forms, and subject-verb agreement—to make the sentence clear and correct.

Overall Feedback  
Your sentence has the right idea—a trip to the store and buying fresh apples—but shifts tense and verb forms, which makes it confusing. I’ll help you choose and stick to one tense, correct irregular verbs, and improve agreement between subjects and verbs.  

Spelling Edits  
• “buyed” → “bought”  
  ­ Issue type: spelling/verb form  
  ­ Rationale: “Buy” is an irregular verb; its past tense is “bought,” not “buyed.”  

Grammar Edits  
• “I was going, then I go to the store,” → consider “I was going to the store” or “I went to the store.”  
  ­ Issue type: tense consistency  
  ­ Rationale: Mixing past continuous (“was going”) with present simple (“go”) confuses the timeline. Pick one tense.  
• “buyed apples” → “bought apples”  
  ­ Issue type: verb form  
  ­ Rationale: Corrects the irregular past-tense form of “buy.”  
• “that is fresh” → “that are fresh” or “which are fresh”  
  ­ Issue type: subject-verb agreement  
  ­ Rationale: “Apples” is plural, so you need “are” instead of “is.”  
• Comma splice in “I was going, then I go to the store”  
  ­ Issue type: run-on sentence  
  ­ Rationale: Two independent ideas shouldn’t be joined by just a comma. You can use a conjunction or split into two sentences.  

Structural Suggestions  
• Combine actions in one flowing sentence: “I went to the store and bought fresh apples.”  
  ­ Improves coherence by using a single past-tense narrative.  
• Or split into two clear sentences:  
  “I was going to the store. I bought fresh apples.”  
  ­ Provides emphasis and avoids run-ons.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add context or detail: Why were you going? For whom?  
• Vary sentence structure: You could start with a reason (e.g., “Because I was out of fruit, I went to the store and bought fresh apples.”)  
• Use descriptive language: Describe the apples or the store to paint a clearer picture.  

Formatting Guidance  
• Ensure each sentence starts with a capital letter and ends with a period.  
• Keep one idea per sentence for clarity.  
• For longer writing, separate paragraphs by topic or action.

coverageText:
Overview  
This feedback focuses on clarifying your one-sentence opening by fixing subject-verb agreement, article use, and verb forms. I’ll also suggest ways to break the sentence for better flow and add small details to engage readers.

Before we begin, could you tell me:  
- What is your goal for this story opening? (e.g., a children’s tale, a sci-fi short story, a writing exercise)  
- What kind of feedback are you looking for? (e.g., grammar only, style and voice, plot development)

Overall Feedback  
Your sentence sets a clear idea—a boy dreaming of space—but it needs grammatical corrections and a stronger structure to make it flow smoothly. Breaking it into two sentences and choosing precise verbs will help readers connect with your character’s ambition right away.

Spelling Edits  
- No spelling errors detected. (Good job with all word spellings.)

Grammar Edits  
- “a boy who are dreams” → “a boy who dreams”  
  Issue type: subject-verb agreement & clarity  
  Rationale: “boy” is singular, so use “dreams” (not “are dreams”). Removing “are” also makes the phrase clearer.

- “to be a astronaut” → “to be an astronaut”  
  Issue type: article usage  
  Rationale: “astronaut” begins with a vowel sound, so the correct article is “an.”

- “he maybe will became” → “he may become” or “he might become”  
  Issue type: verb form & modal verb usage  
  Rationale: “became” is past tense; you want the infinitive “become.” Also, pair the modal “may” or “might” directly with the base verb for correct structure.

Structural Suggestions  
- Split into two sentences:  
  Recommendation: Separate the boy’s dream from the possibility of it happening.  
  How it helps: Two shorter sentences improve pacing and clarity.

- Introduce a little context or detail:  
  Recommendation: Add one descriptive phrase (e.g., “staring up at the night sky”) before mentioning his dream.  
  How it helps: A vivid detail draws readers in and sets the scene immediately.

Opportunities for Improvement  
- Show instead of tell: Rather than stating “he dreams to be an astronaut,” describe what he does (e.g., “he sketches rockets in his notebook”).  
- Add emotion or stakes: Why does he want to become an astronaut? A brief hint at his motivation makes the story more engaging.  
- Transition words: If this opening follows a previous paragraph, consider using “Finally,” “Ever since,” or similar to tie it in smoothly.

Formatting Guidance  
- Paragraphing: For very short openings, one paragraph is fine. If you add more sentences, keep paragraphs to three to five sentences each.  
- Punctuation: After splitting into two sentences, ensure each ends with a period.  
- Title or heading: If this is the start of a short story, consider centering a title above this paragraph.

Would you like me to generate a revised version of this sentence with all changes applied?  
Would you like further assistance or more guidance on any part of this opening?

Could you tell me more about your goals for this writing? For example, who is your intended audience, and are you aiming for a casual blog post, a formal essay, or something else? Knowing this will help me tailor my feedback and edits to what you need.

Overview  
Based on your snippet, I’ll focus on correcting tense and agreement errors, smoothing out dialect changes, and suggesting a clearer, more consistent structure. I’ll also give style tips to keep your tone coherent—either casual or formal—depending on your goal.

Overall Feedback  
• Your piece jumps between past and present tense, which can confuse readers. Picking a single tense (past for “yesterday” stories) will strengthen clarity.  
• The shift from slang (“we be shopping”) to more formal phrasing feels abrupt. Deciding on one tone—casual or formal—and sticking with it will make the writing flow better.  
• The structure is very brief and reads like a series of notes. Organizing it into a clear introduction, body, and conclusion will help readers follow your ideas.

Spelling Edits  
• No misspellings detected in the provided text. (Spelling—everything is spelled correctly.)

Grammar Edits  
• “Yesterday I go to market” → “Yesterday I went to the market.”  
  – Issue: tense consistency and missing article (the). You describe a past event, so use past tense “went” and include “the” before “market.”  
• “we be shopping” → “we were shopping.”  
  – Issue: dialect/tense. Standard past continuous form is “were shopping,” which matches the past-tense narrative.  
• “The essay jump around” → “The essay jumps around.”  
  – Issue: subject-verb agreement and tense. The subject “essay” is singular, so the verb needs –s (“jumps”), and present tense can work if you’re describing the essay’s general behavior.  
• “I write in casual slang, then formal.” → “I write in casual slang, then switch to a formal tone.”  
  – Issue: clarity and style. Adding “switch to” and “tone” clearly signals the shift and makes the sentence more precise.

Structural Suggestions  
• Start with a clear topic sentence: introduce what you’ll discuss (e.g., “Yesterday, I visited the market, but I struggled to keep my writing style consistent.”). This frames the piece.  
• Combine or expand: Rather than four separate fragments, expand each idea into its own sentence or two. For example, describe what happened at the market in one paragraph, then reflect on your writing style in the next.  
• Add a conclusion: Wrap up by stating what you learned (e.g., “I realized that maintaining a single tense and tone helps my readers follow my story.”). This gives your piece a sense of closure.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Transitions: Use words like “First,” “Next,” and “Finally” or phrases like “However” and “As a result” to guide readers smoothly from one point to the next.  
• Detail and examples: Describe what you bought at the market or why you switched styles mid-essay to make your account more engaging.  
• Tone consistency: Decide if you want a conversational or formal essay. If conversational, you can keep some slang but adjust spellings to match standard English rules. If formal, remove all slang.

Formatting Guidance  
• Paragraphing: Group related sentences into paragraphs (e.g., one for the market story, one for style reflection).  
• Headings (for longer essays): If this grows into a longer piece, use headings like “Market Visit” and “Style Reflection” to organize content.  
• Spacing: Leave a blank line between paragraphs for readability.  
• Consistent punctuation: Make sure each sentence ends with a period, question mark, or exclamation point.

Would you like me to produce a fully rewritten version of your text that incorporates these suggestions? Let me know if you need more detailed changes, additional guidance, or if you’d like me to adjust the tone further!

input: instructions: Give 'Structural Suggestions' with concrete reordering and trimming and explain effects on coherence.; writing: Intro: I love science. Body: My experiments sometimes fail and sometimes success. Conclusion: Science is cool.

coverageText:
Could you please share your goals for this piece? For example:  
- What is your purpose (to inform, persuade, entertain)?  
- Who is your intended audience?  
- Are there specific aspects you want me to focus on beyond structure?  

Overview  
This is a very brief essay-style text with a clear introduction–body–conclusion layout. I’ll focus on tightening the structure to improve flow and coherence, ensuring each part leads smoothly to the next and ends on a strong note.

Overall Feedback  
Your writing conveys enthusiasm for science, which is great. Right now, each section is only one sentence long and feels disconnected. By reorganizing and trimming redundant elements, you can create a tighter piece that still highlights your passion but also shows a logical progression from introduction to body to conclusion.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors detected.  

Grammar Edits  
• “sometimes fail and sometimes success” – change to “sometimes fail and sometimes succeed.”  
  – Issue type: grammar (parallel verb structure)  
  – Rationale: Both actions should be verbs (“fail” / “succeed”) for consistency.

Structural Suggestions  
• Merge the three labeled sections into a single paragraph.  
  – Effect on coherence: Removes artificial breaks and creates a smoother read.  

• Reorder the body sentence so the positive outcome comes last:  
  Original: “My experiments sometimes fail and sometimes succeed.”  
  Revised order: “My experiments sometimes fail, but they often succeed.”  
  – Effect on coherence: Ending on success leaves the reader with an upbeat impression.  

• Trim or expand the conclusion to tie back to your opening passion:  
  Option A (trim): Remove “Conclusion: Science is cool.” and append “because it lets me learn from mistakes and discoveries.” to your body.  
  – Effect on coherence: Avoids repetition and directly links your love of science to your experiences.  
  Option B (expand): Replace “Science is cool.” with “Science is cool because every experiment—successful or not—teaches me something new.”  
  – Effect on coherence: Provides a stronger, more specific ending that circles back to your theme.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add a brief specific example of an experiment to illustrate your point and engage the reader.  
• Introduce a transition word (e.g., “however,” “therefore”) between ideas to guide the reader.  
• Develop your conclusion slightly to reinforce why your experiences matter.  

Formatting Guidance  
• Remove the labels “Intro:,” “Body:,” and “Conclusion:” for a more natural flow.  
• Use one or two short paragraphs rather than three single-sentence sections.  
• Ensure consistent paragraph indentation or spacing throughout.  

Would you like me to generate a rewritten version that incorporates these structural changes? Let me know if you need further assistance or more guidance on any point!

coverageText:
Overview  
Based on your note, I’ll treat this as a very brief argumentative statement and focus on making the claim clearer, correcting grammatical issues, improving flow between ideas, and suggesting where to add concrete evidence and examples.  

Overall Feedback  
Your sentence clearly asserts that climate change is real but points out two problems: no supporting data and choppy paragraphs. To strengthen this argument, restate your claim with correct grammar, split it into shorter sentences, and follow up immediately with facts or examples. Then use linking words to smooth the transition between ideas. Finally, maintain a consistent, slightly formal tone throughout.  

Spelling Edits  
• No misspelled words were found in your text.  

Grammar Edits  
• “The argument say climate change is real” → “The argument says that climate change is real”  
  – Issue: subject-verb agreement (grammar). “Argument” is singular, so the verb needs an “s.” Also adding “that” improves clarity.  
• “but I don’t provide any data” → “but it does not provide any data”  
  – Issue: pronoun reference and voice consistency (grammar). Shifting from “I” to “it” keeps the focus on the argument itself rather than the writer.  
• “and the paragraphs is choppy.” → “and the paragraphs are choppy.”  
  – Issue: number agreement (grammar). “Paragraphs” is plural, so use “are.”  

Structural Suggestions  
• Break into two or more sentences:  
  – Suggestion: Move “However” to the start of the second sentence for a clear contrast.  
  – How it helps: Shorter sentences improve readability and emphasize each point.  
• Reorder for emphasis:  
  – Suggestion: First state the claim, then note the lack of data, then mention flow issues.  
  – How it helps: A logical sequence (claim → evidence gap → flow issue) makes your critique easier to follow.  
• Expand each point into its own sentence or paragraph:  
  – Suggestion: After noting “no data,” immediately follow with an example or placeholder where you will insert statistics.  
  – How it helps: Separating ideas gives you room to develop each one fully.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Clarity: Define what “the argument” refers to—yours, someone else’s, or a general claim.  
• Evidence: Add specific data (e.g., “According to the IPCC, global temperatures have risen by 1.1 °C since pre-industrial times.”)  
• Examples: Reference a particular study, event, or statistic to illustrate real-world impact (for instance, melting glaciers in Greenland).  
• Transitions: Use words like “however,” “furthermore,” or “in addition” to link ideas and guide the reader.  
• Tone: Adopt a formal, objective style—avoid contractions (“does not” instead of “don’t”) and keep to third person.  

Formatting Guidance  
• Paragraphing: Keep each main idea in its own paragraph (claim, evidence, flow critique).  
• Headings (if this is part of a longer essay): Use clear labels such as Introduction, Evidence, Discussion, Conclusion.  
• Citations: When you add data, follow a consistent style (APA, MLA, or Chicago) for in-text citations and a reference list.  
• Spacing and indentation: Use standard double-spacing and indent the first line of each paragraph if this is a school assignment.  

Could you tell me more about your goals for this piece (audience, purpose) and what kind of feedback you’d like? Would you like me to generate a revised version of your text incorporating these suggestions, or is there another way I can help?

Well-structured feedback matching required categories and tone.

goals: Strengthen thesis, improve flow, and fix grammar/tense issues

tone_preferences: constructive, encouraging
constraints: keep my voice; do not add new sources; preserve any in-text citations
text: In todays world, social media are making people more connected but also more apart. I think that while it helps us communicate, it also make us lonely, because we are scrolling instead of seeing each other. For example, I text my friends daily but I dont see them on weekend, which used to be normal before. This topic is very important because people are getting worse attention span and that affects school. Some people says social media is just a tool and it depends how you use it, but I think the whole design is addictive. (Turkle 45)
validityText:
No violation.  
OK
coverageText:
Overview  
Based on your goals—strengthening the thesis, improving flow, and fixing grammar/tense issues in an argumentative essay excerpt for a high-school English teacher under MLA expectations—this edit focuses on  
• sharpening your central claim (“thesis”)  
• smoothing sentence and paragraph flow  
• correcting spelling, grammar, and punctuation  
• offering structural tweaks and MLA formatting reminders  

Overall Feedback  
Your paragraph has a clear personal voice and a relevant topic. To meet MLA and argumentative-essay expectations, you’ll want to:  
• State a concise, arguable thesis at the end of your introduction.  
• Ensure each sentence builds logically to your thesis.  
• Use varied sentence structures and clear transitions.  
• Maintain standard MLA conventions (in-text citations, punctuation, header).  

Spelling Edits  
• “In todays world” → “In today’s world”  
  – Issue: missing apostrophe for possession (spelling).  
• “I dont see them” → “I don’t see them”  
  – Issue: missing apostrophe in contraction (spelling).  

Grammar Edits  
• “social media are making people more connected” → “social media is making people more connected”  
  – Issue: collective noun agreement (grammar). “Social media” is treated as a singular concept.  
• “but also more apart.” → “but also more disconnected.”  
  – Issue: word choice for clarity (style). “Disconnected” more directly contrasts “connected.”  
• “it also make us lonely” → “it also makes us lonely”  
  – Issue: subject-verb agreement (grammar). Singular “it” needs “makes.”  
• “I text my friends daily but I dont see them on weekend” → “I text my friends daily, but I don’t see them on the weekend”  
  – Issue: comma before coordinating conjunction (grammar); missing article “the” (grammar); contraction spelling (see above).  
• “which used to be normal before.” → “which used to be normal.”  
  – Issue: redundant “before” after “used to” (conciseness).  
• “people are getting worse attention span” → “people’s attention spans are getting worse”  
  – Issue: possessive form and plural agreement (grammar); awkward word order (clarity).  
• “Some people says social media is just a tool” → “Some people say social media is just a tool”  
  – Issue: subject-verb agreement (grammar).  
• “it depends how you use it” → “it depends on how you use it”  
  – Issue: missing preposition (grammar).  
• Citation placement: “addictive. (Turkle 45)” → “addictive (Turkle 45).”  
  – Issue: period belongs after the full citation (MLA punctuation).  

Structural Suggestions  
• Move your thesis into a single, strong final sentence of the introduction.  
  – Suggestion: End with “While social media helps us communicate across distances, its addictive design often leaves us lonelier and with shorter attention spans, which can hurt our academic focus.” This spotlights your argument and sets up the rest of the essay.  
• Combine short, choppy sentences for better flow:  
  – Merge “I think that while it helps us communicate, it also makes us lonely, because we are scrolling instead of seeing each other.” into one sentence for smoother rhythm.  
• Add a brief context or statistic at the very start as a hook (“According to recent studies, students now scroll over three hours daily on social media.”).  
  – Improves engagement and shows research backing.  
• Use transitions to link ideas clearly:  
  – For instance, begin the attention-span sentence with “Furthermore,” or “Consequently,” to signal cause and effect.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Provide a concrete example or brief anecdote about a specific weekend you missed with friends, to illustrate your point.  
• Define key terms like “addictive design” so your audience knows exactly what features you mean.  
• Vary sentence openings (adverbial phrases, questions) to keep reader interest.  
• Insert a counter-argument sentence and then refute it, to strengthen your persuasive appeal (“Although some argue that user choice matters more than design, research shows…”).  

Formatting Guidance  
• MLA Header and Pagination: Your paper should have a top-left header with your name, instructor, course, and date, and a running header with your last name and page number in the top right.  
• Font and Spacing: Use Times New Roman, 12 pt, double-spaced with 1-inch margins.  
• In-Text Citations: Place citation immediately after the quoted or paraphrased material but before the period—no extra space before the parenthesis.  
• Works Cited Placeholder: At the end, include a “Works Cited” page. List Turkle’s source in proper MLA format, even if you only place a placeholder entry for now.  

Would you like me to produce a fully revised version of this excerpt incorporating these suggestions? Or do you need more targeted guidance on any of these points?
coverageEvalText:
Fits all requested categories, structure, and tone for an editorial pass.  
OK

text: I walk into the old arcade last night and the lights were buzzing like a hive. The air smells of dust and coins. “You coming?” Jay says, but I was already at the claw machine, staring at a plush whale that looks at me like it knows a secret. I drop the token. It clatters. I am thinking this is silly and then the claw was moving and my heart thumped. The whale slips, then it slip again and I laugh, but it sounded too loud in the empty place.

coverageText:
Overview  
This feedback focuses on aligning your short fiction scene with your goals: maintaining a reflective, slightly whimsical first-person voice while improving tense consistency, sharpening clarity in descriptions, and correcting dialogue punctuation. I’ll provide line-by-line notes, pacing and structure suggestions, and show-vs-tell guidance, all tailored for a teen literary magazine submission in standard manuscript format.

Overall Feedback  
Your scene has a charming, immersive start, but shifts in tense and a string of short sentences sometimes interrupt the dreamy, reflective tone you’re aiming for. Strengthening sensory details and varying sentence length will heighten the whimsy. Clear, consistent tense and polished dialogue punctuation will help readers stay grounded in your narrator’s perspective and feel more connected to the moment at the arcade.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors detected. (Spelling: the text’s word choices are correct.)

Grammar Edits  
• “I walk into the old arcade last night” → “I walked into the old arcade last night.”  
  – Issue: tense consistency. You mix present (“walk”) with past (“last night”). Changing “walk” to “walked” keeps past tense throughout the narration.  
• “You coming?” Jay says, but I was already at the claw machine… → Separate into two sentences or use a semicolon. For example: “You coming?” Jay says. I was already at the claw machine…  
  – Issue: run-on sentence and dialogue tag punctuation. Ending the quote with a question mark should be followed by a closing quote and then a period or new sentence before continuing.  
• “I am thinking this is silly and then the claw was moving” → “I think this is silly, and then the claw moved”  
  – Issue: tense consistency and clarity. Changing “am thinking” to simple present (“think”) or past (“thought”) and “was moving” to “moved” aligns your verbs.  
• “The whale slips, then it slip again” → “The whale slips, then it slips again.”  
  – Issue: subject‐verb agreement. “It slip” should be “it slips” to match singular subject “whale.”  
• “I drop the token. It clatters. I am thinking…” → consider merging: “I drop the token; it clatters, and I think…”  
  – Issue: choppy sentence rhythm. Using a semicolon or conjunction binds related actions for smoother flow.

Structural Suggestions  
• Break into paragraphs for better pacing:  
  – Paragraph 1: station arrival and mood (lines about lights buzzing, dusty air).  
  – Paragraph 2: Jay’s dialogue and your diversion to the claw machine.  
  – Paragraph 3: dropping the token and the machine’s action.  
  This separation guides the reader through each beat of the scene and prevents short sentences from running together.  
• Rearrange sensory details to “show” more: start with a small action (like flicking a coin into your palm) before describing smells. This grounds the narrator’s body in the scene, then expands to scent and sound.  
• Introduce internal reflection after action: rather than “I am thinking this is silly” in the middle, you might pause after the claw moves to let the narrator’s thoughts unfold, then return to action. That variation pulls readers deeper into the reflective voice.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Show vs. tell: replace “the air smells of dust and coins” with a brief image, e.g., “I can taste the powdery dust on my tongue and hear the soft jingle of loose change.”  
• Emotional stakes: hint at why the plush whale matters—does it remind the narrator of someone or something? A sentence or two of backstory will deepen engagement.  
• Vary sentence length: mix short, punchy lines with longer, flowing ones to reflect that whimsical tone and keep readers on their toes.

Formatting Guidance  
• Use standard manuscript format: 12-point Courier or Times New Roman, double-spaced, one-inch margins.  
• Dialogue formatting: start a new line each time the speaker changes.  
• Page header: include your last name/scene title and page number in the upper right.  
• Indent first line of each paragraph by ½ inch—don’t add extra spaces between paragraphs in double-spaced prose.

Would you like me to produce a fully revised version of your scene incorporating these edits? Or do you need more guidance on any specific area?
coverageEvalText:
Detailed, categorized, explanatory feedback with constructive tone and formatting advice—meets description.  
OK

Overview  
This feedback focuses on making your complaint email clear, concise, and professionally structured. Based on your goals—professional tone, firm yet polite voice, and retention of order details—we’ll address line-by-line grammar and spelling, suggest ways to tighten the structure, and provide formatting tips to ensure a courteous, actionable message under 250 words.

Overall Feedback  
• Your email conveys the core issue and order details but feels abrupt in places. Softening some phrases will maintain firmness without sounding confrontational.  
• Breaking the body into short, focused paragraphs will improve readability and flow.  
• A clearer subject line and a direct call to action will guide customer service to respond quickly.

Spelling Edits  
• “thats not possible” → “that’s not possible”  
  – Issue: missing apostrophe (spelling). Adding the apostrophe corrects the contraction.  
• No other misspellings detected.

Grammar Edits  
• Salutation: “To whom it may concern,”  
  – Add a comma after “concern” if kept; alternatively use “Hello,” or “Dear Customer Support Team,” for a friendlier tone. (grammar: punctuation)  
• Date format: “Aug 29.” → “August 29,”  
  – Issue: consistency and formality (style). Spelling out the month and adding a comma matches formal email conventions.  
• “This is pretty unacceptable, honestly.” → “This situation is unacceptable.”  
  – Issue: tone (clarity and concision). Removing “pretty” and “honestly” makes the sentence firmer and more professional.  
• “if thats not possible.” → “if that’s not possible.”  
  – Issue: missing apostrophe (spelling) and avoid sentence fragments by connecting ideas smoothly.  

Structural Suggestions  
• Subject Line: Change from “Issue with damaged monitor order” to “Request for Replacement or Refund – Order #A11359”  
  – Improves clarity and urgency, helping the team prioritize.  
• Opening Paragraph: Start by briefly stating your purpose and including order details. For example:  
    “I purchased a 27″ monitor (Order #A11359) on August 29. Upon arrival, I discovered a cracked screen and a dent in the right corner.”  
  – Combines related facts for better flow.  
• Second Paragraph: Describe your attempt to call and the problem with hold times.  
  – Keeps each paragraph focused on a single topic.  
• Closing Paragraph: State your request and ask for next steps.  
  – A clear call to action guides the reader on exactly what to do.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Tone: Replace “To whom it may concern” with a personalized greeting if you have a name.  
• Attachments: Mention “I have attached photos” earlier so it doesn’t get overlooked.  
• Timeline: Specify when you’d like a response (e.g., “within five business days”) to set expectations.

Formatting Guidance  
• Use an email structure:  
   1. Subject line (clear and action-focused)  
   2. Greeting (e.g., “Dear Customer Support Team,”)  
   3. Body (3 short paragraphs: issue description, attempted contact, request)  
   4. Call to action (“Please let me know the next steps.”)  
   5. Signature (name, contact info)  
• Keep paragraphs to 2–4 sentences for readability.  
• Use bullet points only if you list multiple issues or requests.

input:
goals: Ensure scientific clarity, fix passive voice excess, polish tense consistency, and improve figure/table references
type_of_writing: lab report (Introduction and Results excerpts)
target_audience: high school chemistry teacher
feedback_focus: line-by-line grammar and style edits with reasoning; structural suggestions; formatting guidance for figures/tables
formatting: APA headings; proper figure captions; units formatting
tone_preferences: objective, precise
constraints: do not change numerical results; keep equations as-is
text: Introduction: The rate of reaction is being affected by temperature according to the collision theory. It is believed that higher temperature increases kinetic energy and thus more effective collisions occurs. Results: The solution was heated to 30C, 40C, and 50C and the time to color change were recorded as 45s, 31s, and 19s respectively (see table 1). There is an apparent trend showing rate goes up when temperature was raised. Figure 2 shows the line of best fit which seems kind of steep.
