coverageText:
Overview  
Based on your goals for scientific clarity, reduced passive voice, consistent tense, and improved figure/table references, I’ll focus on refining active phrasing, unifying verb tenses, tightening your explanations, and ensuring APA-style headings, captions, and unit formatting.

Overall Feedback  
- You explain collision theory and your results clearly, but several sentences rely on passive voice or mix tenses, which can distract a reader.  
- Switching to active constructions and consistent present tense (for theory) or past tense (for completed experiments) will improve readability.  
- Precise wording in figure/table references and proper unit formatting will meet APA conventions.  
- A more formal style—avoiding informal phrases like “kind of steep”—will suit a high-school chemistry teacher audience.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors detected. All scientific and common terms are spelled correctly.

Grammar Edits  
• “The rate of reaction is being affected by temperature according to the collision theory.”  
  – Revised: “According to collision theory, reaction rate increases as temperature rises.”  
  – Issue: passive voice and wordiness; switched to active voice and concise phrasing.  

• “It is believed that higher temperature increases kinetic energy and thus more effective collisions occurs.”  
  – Revised: “Higher temperature increases kinetic energy, leading to more effective collisions.”  
  – Issue: passive construction (“It is believed”), subject–verb disagreement (“collisions occurs”); corrected to active voice and fixed agreement.  

• “The solution was heated to 30C, 40C, and 50C and the time to color change were recorded as 45s, 31s, and 19s respectively (see table 1).”  
  – Revised: “We heated the solution to 30 °C, 40 °C, and 50 °C, and recorded the time to color change as 45 s, 31 s, and 19 s, respectively (see Table 1).”  
  – Issues: mixed singular/plural (“time … were”), passive voice; missing degree symbol and space before units; “table 1” should be “Table 1” in APA.  

• “There is an apparent trend showing rate goes up when temperature was raised.”  
  – Revised: “The reaction rate increases as temperature increases.”  
  – Issues: mixed tenses (“goes up” vs. “was raised”); informal phrasing (“goes up”); simplified to active present-tense statement of trend.  

• “Figure 2 shows the line of best fit which seems kind of steep.”  
  – Revised: “Figure 2 shows a steep slope for the line of best fit.”  
  – Issues: informal phrase “kind of steep”; clarified “slope” and removed conversational tone.

Structural Suggestions  
• Combine theory and mechanism: Merge your two introductory sentences into one clear statement of principle (as shown above). This improves flow by introducing the key idea up front.  
• Results paragraph order: First reference Table 1 immediately after describing the temperatures, then list the times. This groups related information and helps readers locate details faster.  
• Add a brief concluding sentence in Results: After describing Figure 2, note what the slope indicates (for example, higher rate sensitivity), to close the paragraph with interpretation.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Define variables or acronyms on first use (e.g., “reaction rate (k)”).  
• Comment on experimental uncertainty or replicate trials to strengthen credibility.  
• Include a transition sentence between Introduction and Results to describe your experimental aim.  
• Consider adding numerical r² or correlation coefficients when discussing how well the line of best fit represents data.

Formatting Guidance  
• APA Headings: Use bold, left-aligned Level 1 headings “Introduction” and “Results” (no italics or underlines).  
• Figure/Table Captions:  
  – Table 1 caption goes above the table: “Table 1. Time to Color Change at Different Temperatures.”  
  – Figure 2 caption goes below the figure: “Figure 2. Line of Best Fit for Reaction Rate vs. Temperature.”  
• Units: Always include a space between number and unit (e.g., “30 °C,” “45 s”), and use the degree symbol (°) for Celsius.  
• In-text references: Capitalize “Table” and “Figure,” and italicize numbers only if required by your style guide (not in APA).

Would you like me to generate a fully revised version of your text incorporating these edits? Or would you prefer additional changes, more guidance on any section, or further examples?
coverageEvalText:
Matches required structure: overview, categorized feedback, line-by-line edits with reasoning, closing offer to revise.  
OK

goals: Strengthen narrative arc and clarity while preserving authenticity; refine grammar and tone
type_of_writing: college application personal statement
target_audience: college admissions officers
feedback_focus: line-by-line edits with reasoning; structural suggestions; opportunities for improvement; formatting guidance for 650-word limit

constraints: keep my voice; do not add dialects; do not exaggerate hardships; 650 words max (current draft ~590)
text: Growing up as a first-generation Mexican American, I often translated bank forms for my parents and tried to make sense of bills with unfamiliar words. At first, I felt small in those offices, like I was pretending to be older. Over time, I realized I was learning a language of responsibility. When my mom’s small catering business almost closed during the pandemic, I made flyers, wrote emails, and built a simple website on my cracked phone. It wasn’t perfect, but it worked, and we kept going. This taught me how community isn’t a slogan; it’s people showing up for each other. I still worry about sounding “right,” but I’ve learned to ask questions and keep trying even when I’m unsure. College, to me, is a place to grow that force of trying into something that can help others, especially families navigating systems that pretend to be simple.

Overview  
Based on your goals—to strengthen the narrative arc and clarity while preserving your authentic voice in a college-application personal statement—this edit focuses on:  
- Maintaining your sincere, reflective, confident (but humble) tone  
- Preserving cultural and personal details without exaggeration  
- Clarifying phrasing and tightening language for maximum impact  
- Structuring into clear paragraphs under 650 words  

Overall Feedback  
Your essay offers a compelling snapshot of how you’ve turned real-world challenges into growth. The opening anecdote about translating bank forms immediately establishes your background and responsibility. The pandemic example shows initiative and community values. To strengthen the narrative arc, try tightening some phrases for clarity, breaking the text into distinct paragraphs (introduction, development, reflection, conclusion), and adding a brief detail or two to heighten emotional resonance. Overall, you speak directly to admissions officers with a confident yet humble voice that aligns well with your goals.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors were found in the text. (Spelling: your word choices are correct and free of typos.)

Grammar Edits  
• “that force of trying” → “that force of persistence”  
  ­­Issue type: word choice (clarity)  
  Rationale: Using “persistence” as a noun feels more natural than “trying,” which is gerund-heavy and slightly awkward.  
• In “I made flyers, wrote emails, and built a simple website on my cracked phone,” consider parallel verb forms: “I created flyers, drafted emails, and built a simple website on my cracked phone.”  
  ­­Issue type: parallelism (style)  
  Rationale: Using three verbs of similar register (“created,” “drafted,” “built”) makes the list read more smoothly.  
• “College, to me, is a place to grow that force …” → “To me, college is where I can grow this persistence …”  
  ­­Issue type: sentence structure (clarity)  
  Rationale: Beginning with “To me” and referencing “this persistence” directly ties back to the revised phrase and improves flow.  

Structural Suggestions  
• Break into four paragraphs:  
  ­­1. Introduction (lines 1–2): your first-generation background and translating forms  
  ­­2. Development (lines 3–5): growth of responsibility, pandemic example, action steps  
  ­­3. Reflection (line 6–7): what those experiences taught you about community and asking questions  
  ­­4. Conclusion (line 8): your vision for college and helping others

• Shift the pandemic anecdote (“When my mom’s small catering business …”) to its own paragraph and begin with a more vivid moment—e.g., “I tapped out flyers on my cracked phone in the midst of supply shortages.”  
  Explanation: A stronger opening to that paragraph hooks the reader with sensory detail before summarizing your tasks.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add a specific detail about a bank form or bill you translated (e.g., an overdraft notice or mortgage statement).  
  Explanation: A concrete example deepens authenticity and shows rather than tells your early responsibilities.  
• Briefly mention a skill or insight you hope to build in college (e.g., data analysis, communication workshops).  
  Explanation: Demonstrates that you’ve researched what college can offer you and how you’ll apply it to help families.  
• Strengthen transitions with linking phrases (e.g., “Similarly,” “As a result,” “Building on that lesson”).  
  Explanation: Smooths movement between ideas and reinforces causality in your narrative.  

Formatting Guidance  
• Keep paragraphs short (3–5 sentences) with clear topic sentences; avoids walls of text.  
• Omit headings—use natural breaks and transitions, per admissions essay conventions.  
• Track word count carefully—aim for 630–650 words to leave room for small edits.

goals: Improve word choice, check capitalization and punctuation; preserve line breaks and imagery
type_of_writing: poem (free verse)
target_audience: school literary journal
feedback_focus: line-by-line edits with reasoning; subtle style suggestions; formatting guidance for line breaks/stanzas

tone_preferences: lyrical, contemplative
constraints: maintain metaphors and core images; do not impose rhyme
text: the sun dropps behind the hill—
i chase the day like a late bus,
shoes unlaced, the gravel keeps my secrets.
I call the trees my witnesses
and they don’t answer (they never did)
but the leaves clap anyway, a small stadium.
tomorrow is a folded map in my pocket
that I forgot to unfold.
validityText:
The input is a user-provided piece of writing (a free-verse poem) accompanied by meta-instructions (goals, type_of_writing, target audience, feedback_focus, formatting preferences, tone_preferences, constraints). This aligns exactly with the specification, which allows for natural-language writing plus meta-instructions for editing. There are no disallowed elements or missing requirements.

coverageText:
Overview  
Based on your goals (improving word choice, checking capitalization and punctuation, preserving line breaks and imagery), I’ve taken a close, line-by-line look at your free-verse poem. My edits focus on correcting small errors (spelling, capitalization), tightening punctuation for clarity, offering subtle style suggestions to deepen the lyrical tone, and recommending stanza breaks that respect your core images and metaphors.

Overall Feedback  
Your poem offers vivid, contemplative images—the sun as a setting force, the chase of a waning day, secret-keeping gravel, silent witnesses in the trees, and tomorrow as an unfolded map. To strengthen the lyrical flow for a school literary journal, I recommend consistent capitalization at the start of lines, a single spelling correction, and punctuation tweaks that help guide the reader through each image without imposing rhyme. Small word-choice shifts will sharpen clarity while preserving your metaphors.

Spelling Edits  
• “dropps” → “drops”  
  Issue type: spelling  
  Rationale: “Dropps” is a misspelling. Correcting to “drops” ensures standard spelling and keeps the reader focused on the imagery.  

Grammar Edits  
• Line 1, “the sun dropps behind the hill—” → “The sun drops behind the hill—”  
  Issue type: capitalization, spelling  
  Rationale: Capitalize the first word of a line in English poetry for consistency with conventions; correct “dropps” to “drops.”  
• Line 2, “i chase the day like a late bus,” → “I chase the day like a late bus,”  
  Issue type: capitalization  
  Rationale: Capitalize “I” to follow standard English usage and maintain a polished look in your journal submission.  
• Line 4, “I call the trees my witnesses” → consider “I call the trees my witnesses,” (add comma)  
  Issue type: punctuation  
  Rationale: A trailing comma can create a pause that echoes the breath before “and they don’t answer…” making the rhythm more lyrical.  

Structural Suggestions  
• Group lines 1–2 as Stanza 1 (sun & chase): establishes your opening image and action together, so the reader enters the poem with a clear scene and movement.  
• Group lines 3–4 as Stanza 2 (secrets & witnesses): ties the personal secret to the trees, creating a natural pause before the parenthetical aside.  
• Lines 5–6 as Stanza 3 (leaves applauding): keeps the parenthesis and the applause image tightly connected, emphasizing their quiet energy.  
• Lines 7–8 as Stanza 4 (tomorrow’s map): isolates the final metaphor for emphasis, so the reader lingers on “that I forgot to unfold.”  

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Word choice: consider swapping “keeps my secrets” for something more active—e.g., “harbors my secrets”—to heighten the sense that the gravel is almost alive.  
• Rhythm and line length: shortening or lengthening a line can emphasize key words (for instance, breaking “shoes unlaced” onto its own line for extra space).  
• Sensory detail: you might add a subtle sound or color detail (a whisper of wind, the orange glow on the gravel) to deepen the contemplative tone.  
• Transition words: in Stanza 2 or 3, a gentle connector (like “yet” or “still”) could underline the contrast between silence and the leaves’ applause.  

Formatting Guidance  
• Stanza breaks: use a blank line between each suggested grouping to guide readers through shifts in image or mood.  
• Capitalization: capitalize each line’s first word for a consistent, polished look in a school journal.  
• Em-dashes: retain your em-dash after “hill” but ensure it’s a proper long dash (—) rather than two hyphens.  
• Parentheses vs. dashes: consider replacing the parentheses around “they never did” with em-dashes for stronger emphasis—e.g., and they don’t answer—they never did—but that remains a stylistic choice.  
• Line breaks: preserve your intentional breaks, but feel free to indent the second line of a broken sentence (like lines 7–8) slightly for visual unity.

Would you like me to produce a fully revised version of your poem incorporating these edits? Or is there another aspect you’d like to explore further?
coverageEvalText:
Comprehensive, structured feedback with required categories and reasoning; follows description precisely.  
OK

goals: Clarify thesis and evaluation criteria; fix grammar and tone; suggest structure
type_of_writing: book review
target_audience: classmates and teacher

formatting: MLA for book titles and quotes

text: In The Giver by Lois Lowry, the community seems perfect but actually its not. I liked the way the author use color as a symbol of freedom and choice. When Jonas first sees the apple “change,” it foreshadows him seeing the world differently. The pacing in the middle got slow for me and I think the ending was confusing but good. Overall I would recommend this book because it makes you think about choices and memory and what is price of safety.

The text is provided in-line rather than as an attachment and is within the allowed content types. Therefore, it complies with the input specification.

coverageText:
Overview  
This editorial review focuses on sharpening your thesis and evaluation criteria, tightening grammar and tone, and structuring your book review into the classic intro–summary–analysis–conclusion format. We’ll ensure you meet MLA requirements for book titles and quotes, keep spoilers to the midpoint, and maintain an analytical yet accessible style for classmates and your teacher.

Overall Feedback  
• Thesis clarity: Your review needs a clear evaluative statement up front—what aspect of The Giver you’re judging (symbolism, pacing, ending, etc.) and why those criteria matter.  
• Tone and voice: Shift from casual phrasing (“I liked…”) toward analytical observations supported by evidence. Keep your personal response but frame it in an academic register.  
• Line-by-line polish: Several sentences need subject-verb fixes, punctuation around introductory clauses, and smoother transitions.  
• Structure: Organize into four distinct sections—intro with thesis, concise summary (no major spoilers), analysis paragraphs on symbolism, pacing, ending, and a closing recommendation that ties back to your thesis.

Spelling Edits  
• “its” in “its not.”  
  – Corrected to “it’s” (contraction of “it is”).  
  – Issue: punctuation/grammar—apostrophe needed.

Grammar Edits  
• Original: In The Giver by Lois Lowry, the community seems perfect but actually its not.  
  – Revision: In The Giver by Lois Lowry, the community seems perfect, but it’s not.  
  – Issue: missing comma before “but”; needs “it’s” (contraction) for “it is.”  
• Original: I liked the way the author use color as a symbol of freedom and choice.  
  – Revision: I liked the way the author uses color as a symbol of freedom and choice.  
  – Issue: subject–verb agreement (“author uses”).  
• Original: When Jonas first sees the apple “change,” it foreshadows him seeing the world differently.  
  – Revision: When Jonas first sees the apple “change,” it foreshadows his altered view of the world.  
  – Issue: pronoun (“him” → “his”) and clarity.  
• Original: The pacing in the middle got slow for me and I think the ending was confusing but good.  
  – Revision: The pacing in the middle slowed down, and although the ending was initially confusing, it ultimately proved effective.  
  – Issue: tense consistency, comma splice, and tone—replace “got slow for me” with a more formal structure.  
• Original: Overall I would recommend this book because it makes you think about choices and memory and what is price of safety.  
  – Revision: Overall, I would recommend this book because it prompts readers to consider the connections between choice, memory, and the price of safety.  
  – Issue: missing comma after “Overall,” run-on ideas, awkward word order (“what the price of safety is”).

Structural Suggestions  
• Intro paragraph:  
  – Add a strong thesis sentence that names your evaluation criteria (symbolism, pacing, ending clarity) and your overall judgment.  
  – Explain briefly why these criteria matter to you as a reader.  
• Summary section:  
  – Insert a concise, spoiler-light summary of the plot up to mid-point. One paragraph only.  
  – Avoid revealing events beyond the community’s revelations or Jonas’s first training experiences.  
• Analysis section:  
  – Organize three short paragraphs, each with a clear topic sentence:  
    1. Symbolism of color (quote the apple scene; MLA-cite page).  
    2. Pacing in the middle chapters (give an example of a quieter scene).  
    3. Ending’s clarity (describe what felt confusing and why it still worked).  
  – This improves flow by grouping related ideas.  
• Conclusion paragraph:  
  – Restate your refined thesis and tie it back to why classmates should read it.  
  – Offer a final evaluative statement on the book’s impact.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Transitions: Use linking words (Furthermore, However, In addition) to guide the reader between ideas.  
• Evidence and examples: Integrate at least one direct quote from the text, followed by brief analysis—this strengthens your argument.  
• Balance summary and analysis: Keep the summary short so you have space to analyze key points in depth.  
• Tone: Swap informal phrases (“got slow for me,” “but good”) for more precise academic language (“slowed,” “effective”).

Formatting Guidance  
• MLA book title formatting: Italicize The Giver.  
• Quote formatting: Use quotation marks around any text from the novel, and include an in-text citation—e.g., (Lowry 45).  
• Document style: Double-space your review in 12pt Times New Roman with 1" margins.  
• Paragraphing: Indent the first line of each paragraph one half-inch.  
• Heading (optional): At top left, include your name, teacher’s name, course, and date, double-spaced, then center the title.

Would you like me to generate a fully revised version of your review that incorporates these suggestions? Or is there another area where you’d like more guidance?

Structured, thorough feedback matches all required categories, tone, and bullet usage.  
OK

Overview  
Based on your goals—to improve clarity, ensure consistent tense and style, strengthen the argument’s coherence, and apply Chicago footnote formatting—this feedback focuses on line-level grammar and style edits, concrete structural suggestions, and guidance on placing and formatting footnotes according to the Notes-Bibliography style.

Overall Feedback  
• Your thesis is clear: the New Deal reshaped the citizen–government relationship despite not ending the Depression.  
• Sentence-level phrasing can be tightened for precision (e.g., “both too much and not enough” → “excessive and insufficient”).  
• Maintain consistent past tense when describing historical events.  
• Strengthen coherence by linking your examples directly back to the thesis in each sentence.  
• Ensure footnote markers follow Chicago conventions (placed after punctuation) and include page numbers in the actual footnotes.

Spelling Edits  
• No misspellings found: all words in the excerpt are correctly spelled. (Spelling)

Grammar Edits  
• Subject-verb agreement: In “policies had limits that shows the contradictions,” change shows → show to match plural subject “policies.”  
  – Issue: subject-verb agreement; rationale: “policies” is plural, so the verb must also be plural.  
• Concision and clarity: “were criticized as being both too much and not enough” → “were criticized as both excessive and insufficient.”  
  – Issue: style/clarity; rationale: “excessive and insufficient” is more precise and formal.

Structural Suggestions  
• Combine the first two sentences for a stronger topic sentence:  
  – Move “However” into the same sentence: “Although the New Deal did not end the Great Depression, it redefined the relationship between citizens and the federal government.”  
  – Improvement: creates a single, punchy introduction that clearly states your argument.  
• Tie each example back to your thesis explicitly:  
  – After the CCC example, add a brief clause: “…reinforced certain gender norms, illustrating how relief programs simultaneously advanced and constrained social roles.”  
  – Improvement: reinforces coherence by linking evidence to the central claim.  
• Revise the concluding sentence to preview your paper’s next point or to encapsulate your argument’s implication:  
  – For instance, “Although these reforms were unprecedented in scope, their limitations reveal inherent contradictions that shaped subsequent New Deal policies.”  
  – Improvement: provides a clear transition and emphasizes the argument’s broader significance.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Expand on “reinforced certain gender norms” by briefly noting which norms or expectations were highlighted.  
• Specify which domestic-worker exclusions most affected Black women (e.g., Social Security exclusion) to deepen your evidence.  
• Add transitional phrases (e.g., “Moreover,” “Consequently”) between sentences to guide the reader through your logic.  
• Consider integrating a brief quotation from a primary source, formatted as a Chicago footnote, to strengthen authoritative support.

Formatting Guidance  
• Footnote placement: In Chicago style, place the footnote marker after the sentence’s closing punctuation (e.g., period or comma).  
• Footnote content: Replace [1], [2] placeholders with full citations including author, title, page number.  
• Page numbers: Ensure each footnote lists the specific page(s) you’re citing.  
• Quotation format: If you introduce a direct quote under 100 words, enclose it in quotation marks and cite via footnote. For longer quotations, use block-quote formatting (indented, no quotation marks).  
• Paragraphing: Keep single-idea paragraphs concise (3–5 sentences) to enhance readability.  

Would you like me to generate a revised version of your excerpt that incorporates all these suggestions? Do you need further assistance or additional guidance on any point?

text: Title: How I Stopped Procrastinating By Doing Less
Intro: I used to think I need more apps to fix my procrastination. Turns out, I needed less—less options, less tabs, less guilt.
## Tip 1: Make a Not-To-Do List
This is not negative! It focuses your attention on what you should ignore. For example, checking Twitter every 10 minutes is a bad loop I had.
## Tip 2: Set "good enough" deadlines
Perfectionism is a trap. If you schedule shorter blocks and accept B+ work at first, you will move faster.
## Conclusion
Doing less is surprisingly brave. You will feel weird at first, but then free.

We test filtration rates and particle counts with a DIY microscope rig. Results shows a 42% mean reduction in particles >100 μm after 30 minutes, and 18% reduction in 50–100 μm. Overview  
This feedback focuses on improving tense consistency, clarity, and conciseness while preserving your data. We’ll restructure the abstract into Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusion. Edits will remove first-person phrasing, define acronyms, and ensure a formal, objective tone suitable for science fair judges reviewing a scientific abstract under a 250-word limit.

Overall Feedback  
• Tone and voice: Shift from first-person to passive or neutral constructions (e.g., “was designed” instead of “we designed”).  
• Tense consistency: Use past tense throughout to report completed work.  
• Clarity and conciseness: Eliminate filler phrases (“which is why”), define acronyms (DIY → do-it-yourself), and specify units on first use (micrometer (µm)).  
• Structure: Clearly separate Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusion to guide judges through your study.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors detected. (Spelling check) All technical terms and common words are spelled correctly.

Grammar Edits  
• “Plastic waste in waterways is increasing, which is why we designed a low-cost microplastic filter…”  
  – Suggested: “Plastic waste in waterways is increasing. A low-cost microplastic filter was designed…”  
  – Issue: grammar/tense consistency and avoidance of first-person. Splitting the sentence improves focus.  
• “We test filtration rates and particle counts with a DIY microscope rig.”  
  – Suggested: “Filtration rates and particle counts were measured using a do-it-yourself (DIY) microscope rig.”  
  – Issue: tense consistency (past tense), first-person removal, acronym definition.  
• “Results shows a 42% mean reduction…”  
  – Suggested: “Results show a 42% mean reduction…”  
  – Issue: subject-verb agreement (plural “Results” needs “show”), tense consistency.  
• “18% reduction in 50–100 μm.”  
  – Suggested: “an 18% reduction in particles sized 50–100 micrometers (µm).”  
  – Issue: clarity (state what is reduced), unit definition, avoid dangling phrase.

Structural Suggestions  
• Background: Start with “Plastic waste in waterways is increasing.” This orients the reader immediately.  
• Methods: Combine design and testing description: “A low-cost microplastic filter using natural fibers was designed and tested on local creek samples. Filtration rates and particle counts were measured using a do-it-yourself (DIY) microscope rig.”  
  – Improves flow by grouping all procedural information.  
• Results: Present percentage reductions in one sentence: “Results show a 42% mean reduction in particles larger than 100 micrometers (µm) after 30 minutes and an 18% reduction in particles sized 50–100 µm.”  
  – Consolidates findings for readability.  
• Conclusion: End with limitations and future potential: “Limitations include inconsistent flow and clogging; however, the design can be scaled for classroom use.”  
  – Clearly signals the end of the abstract and its implications.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add context on sample size or number of trials to strengthen credibility.  
• Indicate measurement uncertainty or standard deviation if available.  
• Include a brief statement on the filter’s material properties or cost to highlight “low-cost.”  
• Use transition words (e.g., “however,” “therefore”) to link sentences smoothly.  

Formatting Guidance  
• Keep the entire abstract under 250 words; aim for a single paragraph divided logically by clauses or semicolons.  
• Avoid headers in the submitted abstract unless required; use clear signposting phrases (Background, Methods, etc.).  
• Define all acronyms on first use (e.g., do-it-yourself (DIY), micrometer (µm)).  
• Use SI units and Greek letters correctly (µm for micrometers).  
• Ensure consistent punctuation around percentages and units (e.g., “42 %,” “100 µm”).

Would you like me to generate a rewritten version of your abstract incorporating these suggestions? Do you need any additional guidance or further revisions?
coverageEvalText:
Looks comprehensive, well-structured, and follows the required feedback categories and style guidelines.  
OK

• Strengthen the connection between your personal story and how the scholarship will directly impact your academic progress.

Overview  
Based on your goals—to standardize the narrative in American English, address code-switching, and fix grammar/tense—this edit focuses on keeping your cultural references while converting Spanish phrases into clear, idiomatic English. We’ll preserve your personal voice and conversational tone for your high-school teacher audience.

Overall Feedback  
Your paragraph clearly conveys the challenge and growth in switching between Spanish and English. You have a strong narrative voice and honest reflections, but a few expressions still reflect Spanish structure and there are minor grammar choices that can interrupt flow. Cleaning up these moments will make your experience even more relatable and easy to follow.

Spelling Edits  
- No spelling errors found. Your words are all correctly spelled. (Issue: spelling – no action needed.)

Grammar Edits  
- “Mi familia and I moved to the U.S. when I was 10” → “My family and I moved to the U.S. when I was ten.”  
  • Issue: style/consistency. Rationale: Switching “Mi familia” to “My family” keeps it in standard American English. Spelling out “ten” aligns with conventional age notation in narratives.  
- “at la escuela office” → “at the school office.”  
  • Issue: dialect and clarity. Rationale: Translating “la escuela” to “the school” uses standard terms and removes code-switching mid-sentence.  
- “Sometimes I say things like ‘I have 15 years’ because that’s how we say it in Spanish,” → “Sometimes I say things like ‘I’m 15 years old’ because in Spanish we literally say ‘I have 15 years,’”  
  • Issue: grammar and clarity. Rationale: “I’m 15 years old” is the correct English equivalent. Placing the Spanish phrase in quotation clarifies its origin.  
- “It be confusing switching back and forth,” → “It can be confusing to switch back and forth,”  
  • Issue: tense/formality. Rationale: “It can be confusing” uses a standard modal construction instead of nonstandard “be.”  
- “but I’m learning to slow down and think in English first when needed, and also not be ashamed of speaking both.” → “but I’m learning to slow down, think in English first when I need to, and not be ashamed of speaking both languages.”  
  • Issue: parallel structure. Rationale: Adding “languages” clarifies “both,” and ensuring each verb phrase follows the same pattern improves readability.

- Split the first sentence for clarity. Consider:  
  1) “When I was ten, my family and I moved to the U.S.”

- Move the explanation of “I have 15 years” immediately after mentioning code-switching:

- Include a transition word (however, although, even though) before “but I’m learning…” to strengthen connection between confusion and personal growth.

The problem is small shops don’t have time or money to run ads that works. With our pilot of 18 stores, average foot traffic increased 12% in 6 weeks, with 9 stores renewing for the next quarter. coverageText:
Overview  
This edit focuses on tightening your executive summary for clarity and impact. I’ve guided you to:  
- Clarify the **value proposition** and **problem statement** up front  
- Use a consistent, confident tone without hype  
- Fix small grammar and punctuation issues  
- Restructure into clear sections (Value Proposition, Problem, Pilot Results, Growth Plan, Risks & Mitigation)  
- Format with H2/H3 headings, bullets, and bold key metrics  

Overall Feedback  
Your summary clearly presents the core idea and impressive pilot metrics. To sharpen its impact for small business owners, let’s:  
- Lead with a concise **value proposition**  
- State the **problem** in one punchy sentence  
- Combine pilot results into a tight bullet list for scannability  
- Sequence content in a logical flow (What, Why, How, Results, Next Steps)  
- Keep tone confident and direct, removing words that dilute authority (for example, “simple” or “which we plan to”)  

Spelling Edits  
- “ads that works” → “ads that work”  
  Rationale (grammar): Corrects subject–verb agreement  

Grammar Edits  
- Original: “small shops don’t have time or money to run ads that works.”  
  Correction: “small shops don’t have time or money to run ads that work.”  
  Issue (grammar): Subject–verb agreement  

- Original: “With our pilot of 18 stores, average foot traffic increased 12% in 6 weeks, with 9 stores renewing for the next quarter.”  
  Correction: “In our pilot of 18 stores, average foot traffic increased by 12% over six weeks; nine stores have already renewed for the next quarter.”  
  Issue (grammar/clarity): Avoid comma splice; spell out “six”—improves readability  

- Original: “break-even at 320 paying locations”  
  Correction: “achieve break-even at 320 paying locations”  
  Issue (clarity): Adds verb to complete the thought  

- Original: “Risks include churn and notification fatigue which we plan to mitigate with controls.”  
  Correction: “Risks include churn and notification fatigue, which we plan to mitigate through specific controls.”  
  Issue (grammar/clarity): Adds missing comma and clarifies “controls”  

Structural Suggestions  
- Reorder into clear subsections:  
  H2 Value Proposition → H2 Problem → H2 Pilot Results → H2 Growth Plan → H2 Risks & Mitigation  
  This creates a logical narrative arc from what you do to how you’ll scale.  
- Under “Pilot Results,” use bullets for each key metric (e.g., “+12% foot traffic,” “50% renewal rate”) so metrics stand out.  
- Combine redundant phrases (“using geo-targeted notifications and simple onboarding”) into one succinct phrase under Value Proposition.  
- Expand “controls” slightly (for example, “frequency caps” or “opt-out options”) to show concrete planning.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
- Add a brief example or testimonial from one pilot store to humanize the data.  
- Quantify cost savings or ROI if available (e.g., “cost per new customer decreased by 20%”).

Overview  
This feedback focuses on turning your persuasive speech outline into a smooth, 5–6-minute presentation for your classmates. We’ll refine grammar and transitions, strengthen the motivational but grounded tone, and reorganize content so each section flows logically. Finally, you’ll get clear formatting guidance for your speaking notes, including cue words and spacing.

Overall Feedback  
• You have a strong, relatable hook and a clear problem–solution structure.  
• The evidence section needs more concrete details and smoother transitions to keep your classmates engaged.  
• Addressing the counterargument is effective but could use a transition phrase and brief explanation to strengthen your point.  
• Your three-step solution is concise, but you can expand each step slightly to meet the time requirement and make it actionable.  
• Close with a powerful call to action—spell out exactly what you want your peers to do over the next seven days.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors found. (Spelling check) Your outline’s key words are all spelled correctly.

Grammar Edits  
• “Screen time going up; attention going down.”  
  – Corrected: “Screen time is increasing, and attention spans are decreasing.”  
  – Issue: grammar (subject–verb agreement) and clarity. Adding verbs makes it a complete sentence and keeps the parallel structure.  
• “grades slipping, sleep shorter, I felt it last semester.”  
  – Corrected: “Grades are slipping, sleep is shorter, and I felt these effects last semester.”  
  – Issue: parallel structure and clarity. Use full verbs and consistent phrasing for each item.  
• “Phones are tools—yes, but tools shape us.”  
  – Corrected: “Phones are tools, yes, but these tools shape us.”  
  – Issue: punctuation. A comma after “tools” softens the break and improves flow.  
• “Ask audience to try it for 7 days.”  
  – Corrected: “Ask the audience to try these steps for seven days.”  
  – Issue: clarity and style. Spell out “seven” (style) and specify “these steps” so the call to action is clear.

Structural Suggestions  
• Hook → Problem/Evidence: After your hook, add a one-sentence transition like, “Here’s why that matters to all of us.” This will guide listeners into the problem.  
• Combine “Problem” and “Evidence”: Rather than separate bullets, narrate: “Over the last year, my average screen time shot up by two hours a day, my grades dipped from a B+ to a B–, and I was waking up exhausted.” This merges evidence and personal anecdote for impact.  
• Counterargument placement: Introduce it with “Now, you might be thinking…” This sets up the objection before you refute it.  
• Solution expansion: Label each step (“Step 1: Switch to grayscale,” etc.), then add a brief “why this works” sentence under each. That helps fill time and gives classmates context.  
• Close with call to action: End with a clear challenge—“Will you join me in regaining control of your attention? Let’s start today, for the next seven days.” This frames the ask as a group effort.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add a brief data point or statistic (e.g., average teen screen time) to strengthen your evidence.  
• Use a short personal story or visual image to make the problem relatable.  
• Include a rhetorical question or quick audience poll (“How many of you check Instagram first thing?”) for engagement.  
• Vary sentence length and tone—mix shorter, punchy lines with longer, explanatory ones to maintain interest.

Formatting Guidance  
• Headings: Label each main section in your notes—HOOK, PROBLEM, EVIDENCE, COUNTERARGUMENT, SOLUTION, CALL TO ACTION.  
• Cue words: Insert [PAUSE] after your hook, [EMPHASIZE] before a key fact, [LOOK AROUND] when engaging classmates.  
• Spacing: Leave one line blank between sections so you can turn pages without losing your place.  
• Indentation: Use bullet points for sub-ideas under each heading, and number your three steps clearly.  
• Timing notes: In the margin, jot time targets (e.g., “1 min for Hook,” “2 min for Evidence”) to stay within 5–6 minutes.

Overview  
Based on your goals—making the email polite and clear, fixing grammar and formatting, and suggesting a strong professional structure—I’ve focused on clarity, formality, and concise phrasing appropriate for a college-level email to a professor. Key areas include hyphenation, date and time formatting, paragraph division, and a more specific subject line.

Overall Feedback  
Your draft is concise and respectful, which fits your tone preference. To increase clarity and formality, I recommend:
• Hyphenating compound modifiers and spelling out months in full.  
• Splitting the body into two short paragraphs (context then request) for better flow.  
• Adding a brief opening line (e.g., “I hope you are well”) to soften the request.  
• Refining the subject line to state the exact request (“48-Hour Extension”).  

Spelling Edits  
• None detected – all words are spelled correctly.

Grammar Edits  
• Original: “I am requesting a 48 hour extension for the research brief due Sept 28.”  
  Correction: “I am requesting a 48-hour extension for the research brief due September 28.”  
  Reasoning: Hyphenate the compound adjective “48-hour” (grammar) and spell out the month for formality (style).

• Original: “If approved, I will submit by Sept 30 at 11:59pm.”  
  Correction: “If approved, I will submit it by September 30 at 11:59 p.m.”  
  Reasoning: Add the pronoun “it” for clarity (grammar), spell out the month (style), and format time with periods and a space before “p.m.” (style/consistency).

Structural Suggestions  
• Add a brief opener: Insert “I hope you are well.” before stating your request. This enhances tone and rapport.  
• Divide the body into two paragraphs:  
  – Paragraph 1: Context (“I have completed most of the reading, but I need extra time…”)  
  – Paragraph 2: Request and deadline (“Would you please grant me…” + specify new date/time).  
  This separation improves readability and highlights the request.  
• Refine the subject line: Change it to “Request for 48-Hour Extension on Research Brief Due September 28.” A precise subject helps your professor immediately know what you need.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Consider adding a one-sentence expression of gratitude in advance (“I appreciate your understanding and support.”) to strengthen politeness.  
• Use “would you please” instead of “I am requesting” to soften the tone.  
• Confirm receipt: you might add, “Please let me know if this is acceptable.” to invite a reply.

Formatting Guidance  
• Subject Line: Make it action-oriented and specific (see Structural Suggestions).  
• Greeting: “Dear Professor Ahmed,” is slightly more formal than “Hi Professor Ahmed,” but either is acceptable.  
• Opening Line: A brief pleasantry (“I hope you’re doing well.”).  
• Paragraphing: Two short paragraphs as outlined above.  
• Closing: Use “Thank you for your time and consideration.”  
• Sign-off: “Sincerely,” or “Best regards,” followed by your full name on the next line.  
• Spacing: Single-space within paragraphs, double-space between paragraphs and around signature.

Your paragraph effectively highlights how the storm scene establishes tension and foreshadows the film’s survival theme. To sharpen it for a blog audience, I recommend:  
- Naming or specifying “the commander” for clarity

- Varying sentence structure to improve flow

• “it put us in chaos” → “it puts the audience in chaos.”

  – Correction: “‘Everybody can learn to code,’ she said. ‘We just need a place to try and fail safely.’”  
  – Reason: Separate into two sentences for clarity; capitalize “We” per standard sentence rules (AP style).

• “The club has students from different backgrounds and abilities and they pair up to solve small problems.”  
  – Issue: missing comma or conjunction (grammar)  
  – Correction: “The club has students from different backgrounds and abilities, and they pair up to solve small problems.”  
  – Reason: Add comma before “and” linking two independent clauses (comma use).

• “Last week they built an app that shows bus schedules, it was buggy but then they fixed it together.”  
  – Issue: comma splice (grammar)  
  – Correction: “Last week, they built an app that shows bus schedules. It was buggy, but they fixed it together.”  
  – Reason: Split into two sentences to avoid comma splice; add comma before “but” in a compound sentence.

Structural Suggestions  
1. Lead with context: Begin with the school name and number of club members.  
   – Example: “At Lincoln High School, 15 students come together every Wednesday after class…”  
   – Improves reader orientation and stakes.  
2. Break into paragraphs:  
   – Paragraph 1: Introduction of Ms. Johnson and club purpose.  
   – Paragraph 2: Include her quote about coding.  
   – Paragraph 3: Describe student collaboration and recent project.  
   – Paragraph 4: Concluding atmosphere and future plans.  
   – Adds visual breaks and logical flow.  
3. Close with impact: Add a final quote or statistic about student success or upcoming showcase.  
   – Strengthens conclusion and leaves readers with a clear takeaway.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add specific student voices or a short quote (with permission) to illustrate “different backgrounds.”  
• Provide concrete examples of problem-solving challenges to deepen reader engagement.  
• Use transition words (“For example,” “As a result,” “Next”) for smoother connections between ideas.  
• Mention the club’s meeting time or location for practical value to readers.

Formatting Guidance  
• AP style for titles: Use “Ms. Johnson” on first reference without academic degrees; thereafter use “Johnson.”  
• Numbers: Spell out numbers under 10 (e.g., “five students”), use numerals for 10 and above.  
• Quotes: Double quotes for all speech; separate distinct sentences into their own quoted blocks with proper attribution.  
• Paragraphing: Keep each main idea in its own paragraph.  
• Dates/times: Write as “4 p.m. Tuesdays” (lowercase abbreviations, periods in a.m./p.m.).
